Even relatively small numbers of people with advanced botulinum poisoning would require intensive respiratory therapy, and very few hospitals would have readily on hand the numbers of such respirators they might need if they had a surge in cases of botulinum poisoning.

Actually, it exists in several forms.
The basic form is what we call a push package, and those exist in 12 strategically selected locations around the country.

Each push package has enough materiel--drugs and other items, including respirators--to fill the belly of a 747 transport, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which manages this, has developed the capability to get the push package virtually anywhere in the country within 12 hours, and, for many major cities, within four hours.
We think of the push package as a Whitman's Sampler.
It's got a bit of everything that we have in it because we may not know exactly the nature or full scope of the threat at the early stage of an incident.

But in addition, we also have contracts with a number of vendors producing antibiotics, respirators, other medical equipment, where the vendors produce and maintain within their own inventory systems materiel that we own and we can call upon when we know we have a specific need for that materiel.
We call it vendor-managed inventory.

So between these two modalities of these distributed warehouses, plus the stocks held by the vendors themselves, we think we have a robust and a very flexible and very rapidly deployable set of capability.

But we have the problem that pharmaceuticals have a shelf life.
And one of the management challenges for the stockpile is to turn over the materiel in a way that ensues that we always have materiel in the stockpile that is within its rated shelf life.

That has involved arrangements with the Veterans Administration, and that for some of our pharmaceuticals we're able to procure them in a way that as product begins to approach its expiration date, but still has plenty of time left, we can get it into the medical system, and replace it with new materiel, freshly manufactured, but we then have several years of shelf life.

In addition, we have a special arrangement with the Food and Drug Administration that's called shelf-life extension, which so long as our stockpile warehouses and the manufacturers can demonstrate they have the adequate environmental controls for the product, and have a sampling system that tests the potency of the materiel, we can get authorization to hold that materiel longer than what would be its normally rated shelf life and have it re-labeled and appropriate for use over that longer period of time.

But as you might guess, that has an overhead expense associated with it for the testing and the record-keeping and assuring that materiel available at any time is, in fact, good, safe and appropriate for use.
